comment.author: 29048217@N05
comment._content: This looks like the experimental equipment for determining the existence of the ether in space. This was the Michaelson Morley experiment.

comment.author: 36165516@N04
comment._content: I thought these images are found in the Abbott or Langley collections?

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/kinorama] Kinorama/Mike: There was never a solid, established, connection to any one collection for the Smillie cyanotypes. The decision was made in 2005 to simply include them in RU 95, which is an artificial collection of photographic material documenting Smithsonian history. They are included now, together, in our item-level database for images in that collection.

comment.author: 36165516@N04
comment._content: That's great to hear of the database. I can't remember if there are any surviving glass negatives from Smillie's era and if there are any matching cyanotypes, but I have wondered if the cyanotypes served as a visual reference for his photography. I looked and could not find a lot of evidence either. I am glad to see this effort being put up for consumption. Kudos!
